article_title: The potential for artificial intelligence in healthcare
author: Davenport T, Kalakota R
summary: This paper examines the current state and potential future applications of AI in healthcare, highlighting the shift from early rule-based systems to modern machine learning approaches.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Recent years have witnessed the profound integration of artificial intelligence (AI) technologies across healthcare domains, from diagnostic assistance to treatment optimization and clinical prediction.
paper_reference: Davenport T, Kalakota R. The potential for artificial intelligence in healthcare. Future Healthc J. 2019;6(2):94-98.
abstract: The complexity and rise of data in healthcare means that artificial intelligence (AI) will increasingly be applied within the field. Several types of AI are already being employed by payers and providers of care, and life sciences companies. The key categories of applications involve diagnosis and treatment recommendations, patient engagement and adherence, and administrative activities. Although there are many instances in which AI can perform healthcare tasks as well or better than humans, implementation factors will prevent large-scale automation of healthcare professional jobs for a considerable period. Ethical issues in the application of AI to healthcare are also discussed.

article_title: Machine learning in medicine
author: Rajkomar A, Dean J, Kohane I
summary: This landmark paper published in the New England Journal of Medicine provides a comprehensive overview of machine learning applications in medicine, including clinical decision support, population health management, and administrative applications.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Artificial intelligence and machine learning methods represent a significant departure from traditional statistical approaches in healthcare analytics.
paper_reference: Rajkomar A, Dean J, Kohane I. Machine learning in medicine. N Engl J Med. 2019;380(14):1347-1358.
abstract: Machine learning is a computational tool used to aid prediction, classification, and clustering. Powered by artificial intelligence, it can identify patterns in data that might otherwise be missed. In health care, machine learning can help predict who will develop a disease and whether treatment will be effective. Machine learning is an application of artificial intelligence that enables systems to learn from data and improve from experience without being explicitly programmed. Machine-learning systems can be designed to learn from and make predictions on health care data.

article_title: Deep learning for healthcare: review, opportunities and challenges
author: Miotto R, Wang F, Wang S, Jiang X, Dudley JT
summary: This review examines how deep learning techniques are being applied to address problems in healthcare, with a focus on understanding the capabilities and limitations of neural network architectures in clinical applications.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: The technical foundation of healthcare AI has evolved substantially, with deep learning frameworks demonstrating particularly promising results across numerous clinical applications.
paper_reference: Miotto R, Wang F, Wang S, Jiang X, Dudley JT. Deep learning for healthcare: review, opportunities and challenges. Brief Bioinform. 2018;19(6):1236-1246.
abstract: Gaining knowledge and actionable insights from complex, high-dimensional and heterogeneous biomedical data remains a key challenge in transforming health care. Various types of data have been emerging in modern biomedical research, including electronic health records, imaging, -omics, sensor data and text, which are complex, heterogeneous, poorly annotated and generally unstructured. Traditional data mining and statistical learning approaches typically need to first perform feature engineering to obtain effective and more robust features from those data, and then build prediction or clustering models on top of them. There are lots of challenges on both steps in a scenario of complicated data and lacking of sufficient domain knowledge. The latest advances in deep learning technologies provide new effective paradigms to obtain end-to-end learning models from complex data. In this article, we review the recent literature on applying deep learning technologies to advance the health care domain. Based on the analyzed work, we suggest that deep learning approaches could be the vehicle for translating big biomedical data into improved human health. However, we also note limitations and needs for improved methods development and applications, especially in terms of ease-of-understanding for domain experts and citizen scientists. We discuss such challenges and suggest developing holistic and meaningful interpretable architectures to bridge deep learning models and human interpretability.

article_title: Clinical applications of natural language processing for clinical decision support
author: Wang Y, Wang L, Rastegar-Mojarad M, Liu S, Shen F, Liu H
summary: This study details the application of NLP techniques to extract clinically relevant information from unstructured medical text, demonstrating improvements in information extraction efficiency and accuracy.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Natural Language Processing (NLP), a specialized branch of AI focused on human language interpretation, has emerged as a particularly valuable capability for healthcare systems, enabling automated extraction of clinically relevant information from unstructured documentation.
paper_reference: Wang Y, Wang L, Rastegar-Mojarad M, et al. Clinical information extraction applications: A literature review. J Biomed Inform. 2018;77:34-49.
abstract: With the rapid adoption of electronic health records (EHRs), it is desirable to harvest information and knowledge from EHRs to support automated systems at the point of care and to enable secondary use of EHRs for clinical and translational research. One critical component used to facilitate the secondary use of EHR data is the information extraction (IE) task, which automatically extracts and encodes clinical information from text. In this literature review, we present a review of recent published research on clinical information extraction (IE) applications. A literature search was conducted for articles published from January 2009 to September 2016 based on Ovid MEDLINE In-Process & Other Non-Indexed Citations, Ovid MEDLINE, Ovid EMBASE, Scopus, Web of Science, and ACM Digital Library. A total of 1917 publications were identified for title and abstract screening. Of these publications, 263 articles were selected and discussed in this review in terms of publication venues and data sources, clinical IE tools, methods, and applications in the areas of disease- and drug-related studies, and clinical workflow optimizations. Clinical IE has been used for a wide range of applications, however, there is a considerable gap between clinical studies using EHR data and studies using clinical IE. This study enabled us to gain a more concrete understanding of the gap and to provide potential solutions to bridge this gap.

article_title: A systematic review of social determinants of health in electronic health records and their impact on analysis and risk prediction
author: Chen M, Tan X, Padman R
summary: This systematic review examines how social determinants of health are represented in electronic health records and evaluates their impact on healthcare analytics and risk prediction models.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Traditional clinical prediction models have been constrained by their limited capacity to incorporate non-clinical factors that profoundly influence health outcomes.
paper_reference: Chen M, Tan X, Padman R. Social determinants of health in electronic health records and their impact on analysis and risk prediction: A systematic review. J Am Med Inform Assoc. 2020;27(11):1764-1773.
abstract: This integrative review identifies and analyzes the extant literature to examine the integration of social determinants of health (SDoH) domains into electronic health records (EHRs), their impact on risk prediction, and the specific outcomes and SDoH domains that have been tracked. In accordance with the PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses) guidelines, we conducted a literature search in the PubMed, CINAHL, Cochrane, EMBASE, and PsycINFO databases for English language studies published until March 2020 that examined SDoH domains in the context of EHRs. Our search strategy identified 71 unique studies that are directly related to the research questions. 75% of the included studies were published since 2017, and 68% were U.S.-based. 79% of the reviewed articles integrated SDoH information from external data sources into EHRs, and the rest of them extracted SDoH information from unstructured clinical notes in the EHRs. We found that all but 1 study using external area-level SDoH data reported minimum contribution to performance improvement in the predictive models. In contrast, studies that incorporated individual-level SDoH data reported improved predictive performance of various outcomes such as service referrals, medication adherence, and risk of 30-day readmission. We also found little consensus on the SDoH measures used in the literature and current screening tools. The literature provides early and rapidly growing evidence that integrating individual-level SDoH into EHRs can assist in risk assessment and predicting healthcare utilization and health outcomes, which further motivates efforts to collect and standardize patient-level SDoH information.

article_title: About Social Determinants of Health (SDOH)
author: World Health Organization
summary: The WHO provides a comprehensive definition and framework for understanding social determinants of health, emphasizing their importance in addressing health inequities globally.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Social determinants of health encompass the conditions in which people are born, grow, live, work, and age, including factors such as economic stability, educational access, physical environment, social context, and healthcare accessibility.
paper_reference: World Health Organization. Social determinants of health. Published 2023. Accessed May 1, 2025.
abstract: The social determinants of health are the conditions in which people are born, grow, work, live and age, and the wider forces that shape the conditions of daily life. Most of our health is determined by these non-medical root causes of ill health, which include quality education, access to nutritious food, and decent housing and working conditions. Wider forces include economic policies and systems, development agendas, social norms, social policies and political systems. Social determinants of health matter because addressing them not only helps prevents illness but also promotes healthy lives and equity. Health follows a social gradient whereby the more deprived the area in which people live, the lower their income, the fewer their years of education, the worse their health and the fewer healthy years they can expect to live. Governance processes need to ensure that policies and systems are developed and implemented to ensure everyone can realize the conditions needed for a healthy and decent life.

article_title: Social determinants of health inequalities
author: Marmot M
summary: This foundational paper examines the causal pathways through which social factors influence health outcomes and create health disparities across populations.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: These factors exert profound influence on health outcomes through multiple mechanisms, including differential exposure to health risks, variable access to preventive services, disparate treatment efficacy, and uneven distribution of healthcare resources.
paper_reference: Marmot M. Social determinants of health inequalities. Lancet. 2005;365(9464):1099-1104.
abstract: The gross inequalities in health that we see within and between countries present a challenge to the world. That there should be a spread of life expectancy of 48 years among countries and 20 years or more within countries is not inevitable. A burgeoning volume of research identifies social factors at the root of much of these inequalities in health. Social determinants are relevant to communicable and non-communicable disease alike. Health status, therefore, should be of concern to policy makers in every sector, not solely those involved in health policy. As a response to this global challenge, WHO is launching a Commission on Social Determinants of Health, which will review the evidence, raise societal debate, and recommend policies with the goal of improving health of the world's most vulnerable people. A major thrust of the Commission is turning public-health knowledge into political action.

article_title: Moving electronic medical records upstream: Incorporating social determinants of health
author: Gottlieb LM, Tirozzi KJ, Manchanda R, Burns AR, Sandel MT
summary: This paper discusses strategies for integrating SDOH data into electronic health records and examines the challenges and opportunities this integration presents.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: The recognition of SDOH's critical importance has prompted healthcare systems to develop more comprehensive frameworks for data collection, analysis, and intervention that extend beyond traditional clinical parameters.
paper_reference: Gottlieb LM, Tirozzi KJ, Manchanda R, Burns AR, Sandel MT. Moving electronic medical records upstream: Incorporating social determinants of health. Am J Prev Med. 2015;48(2):215-218.
abstract: Electronic health records (EHRs) are a powerful tool for tracking health conditions and risk behaviors but typically contain limited information on social determinants of health that can influence patient health outcomes and clinical care. Just as screening for risk behaviors like smoking is standard practice today but was rare 20 years ago, collecting information about patients' social circumstances—and working with community partners to address identified needs—might one day be standard of care. Greater integration of health and social care could improve referral systems, stimulate innovations in care delivery, and ultimately lead to better patient outcomes. Innovations that make the collection and presentation of social data in EHRs more accurate and efficient—and increasingly standardized—are needed. Without adequately addressing socioeconomic, environmental, and psychosocial factors, new care models aimed at improving population health will lose potential effectiveness. The social history in medicine must be updated for the 21st century to reflect growing evidence on the contribution of social factors to health outcomes.

article_title: SBDH-Reader: an LLM-powered method for extracting social and behavioral determinants of health from medical notes
author: Gu Z, He L, Naeem A, Chan PM, Mohamed A, Khalil H, et al.
summary: This study presents a novel method using large language models to accurately extract social determinants of health information from unstructured clinical notes with high precision.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Particularly noteworthy is the emergence of large language models (LLMs) that can extract social determinant information from unstructured clinical documentation with unprecedented accuracy.
paper_reference: Gu Z, He L, Naeem A, Chan PM, Mohamed A, Khalil H, et al. SBDH-Reader: an LLM-powered method for extracting social and behavioral determinants of health from medical notes. medRxiv. 2025.
abstract: Introduction: Social and behavioral determinants of health (SBDH) are increasingly recognized as essential for prognostication and informing targeted interventions. While medical notes contain rich SBDH details, these are unstructured and conventional extraction methods tend to be labor intensive, inaccurate, and/or unscalable. The emergence of large language models (LLMs) presents an opportunity to develop more effective approaches for extracting SBDH data. Materials and Methods: We developed the SBDH-Reader, an LLM-powered method to extract structured SBDH data from full-length medical notes through prompt engineering. Six SBDH categories were queried including: employment, housing, marital relationship, and substance use including alcohol, tobacco, and drug use. The development dataset included 7,225 notes from 6,382 patients in the MIMIC-III database. The method was then independently tested on 971 notes from 437 patients at UT Southwestern Medical Center (UTSW). We evaluated SBDH-Reader's performance using precision, recall, F1, and confusion matrix. Results: When tested on the UTSW validation set, the GPT-4o-based SBDH-Reader achieved a macro-average F1 ranging from 0.85 to 0.98 across six SBDH categories. For clinically relevant adverse attributes, F1 ranged from 0.94 (employment) to 0.99 (tobacco use). When extracting any adverse attributes across all SBDH categories, the SBDH-Reader achieved an F1 of 0.96, recall of 0.97, and precision of 0.96 in this independent validation set. Conclusion: A general-purpose LLM can accurately extract structured SBDH data through effective prompt engineering. The SBDH-Reader has the potential to serve as a scalable and effective method for collecting real-time, patient-level SBDH data to support clinical research and care.

article_title: Natural Language Processing and Social Determinants of Health in Mental Health Research: AI-Assisted Scoping Review
author: Scherbakov DA, Hubig NC, Lenert LA, Alekseyenko AV, Obeid JS
summary: This AI-assisted scoping review examines the application of NLP techniques to extract and analyze social determinants of health in mental health research.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: These models can identify explicit mentions of housing instability, food insecurity, transportation barriers, and other social factors documented in clinical narratives, enabling automated structuring of previously inaccessible information.
paper_reference: Scherbakov DA, Hubig NC, Lenert LA, Alekseyenko AV, Obeid JS. Natural Language Processing and Social Determinants of Health in Mental Health Research: AI-Assisted Scoping Review. JMIR Ment Health. 2025;12:e67192.
abstract: Background: The use of natural language processing (NLP) in mental health research is increasing, with a wide range of applications and datasets being investigated. Objective: This review aims to summarize the use of NLP in mental health research, with a special focus on the types of text datasets and the use of social determinants of health (SDOH) in NLP projects related to mental health. Methods: The search was conducted in September 2024 using a broad search strategy in PubMed, Scopus, and CINAHL Complete. All citations were uploaded to Covidence (Veritas Health Innovation) software. The screening and extraction process took place in Covidence with the help of a custom large language model (LLM) module developed by our team. This LLM module was calibrated and tuned to automate many aspects of the review process. Results: The screening process, assisted by the custom LLM, led to the inclusion of 1768 studies in the final review. Most of the reviewed studies (n=665, 42.8%) used clinical data as their primary text dataset, followed by social media datasets (n=523, 33.7%). The United States contributed the highest number of studies (n=568, 36.6%), with depression (n=438, 28.2%) and suicide (n=240, 15.5%) being the most frequently investigated mental health issues. Traditional demographic variables, such as age (n=877, 56.5%) and gender (n=760, 49%), were commonly extracted, while SDOH factors were less frequently reported, with urban or rural status being the most used (n=19, 1.2%). Over half of the citations (n=826, 53.2%) did not provide clear information on dataset accessibility, although a sizable number of studies (n=304, 19.6%) made their datasets publicly available. Conclusions: This scoping review underscores the significant role of clinical notes and social media in NLP-based mental health research. Despite the clear relevance of SDOH to mental health, their underutilization presents a gap in current research. This review can be a starting point for researchers looking for an overview of mental health projects using text data. Shared datasets could be used to place more emphasis on SDOH in future studies.

article_title: AI-Ready Multimodal Data Pipeline to Enrich Cancer Care
author: Rashid R, Hashtarkhani S, Kumsa FA, Chinthala L, White BM, Zink JA, et al.
summary: This paper describes a comprehensive approach for integrating multiple data modalities including structured EHR data, clinical notes, and social determinants information to improve cancer care prediction models.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Multimodal data integration approaches further extend these capabilities, enabling simultaneous incorporation of structured clinical data, unstructured documentation, community-level indicators, and even non-traditional sources.
paper_reference: Rashid R, Hashtarkhani S, Kumsa FA, Chinthala L, White BM, Zink JA, et al. AI-ready multimodal data pipeline to enrich cancer care. 2024 IEEE International Conference on Big Data (Big Data). 2024:8814-8822.
abstract: This study reports on the progress in designing and developing a framework for integrating heterogeneous datasets—structured, semi-structured, and unstructured—into an AI-ready multimodal data pipeline aimed at predicting radiation therapy interruptions (RTI) and enhancing patient care navigation. The AI-Ready dataset incorporates a broad set of information, including patient demographics, health data, clinical notes, medical imaging, and data on social determinants of health. Preliminary results indicate that this pipeline effectively integrates diverse distributed data sources, providing a foundation for training AI models capable of generating reliable and actionable predictions.

article_title: The association between income and life expectancy in the United States, 2001-2014
author: Chetty R, Stepner M, Abraham S, Lin S, Scuderi B, Turner N, et al.
summary: This groundbreaking study quantified the relationship between income and life expectancy across the United States, demonstrating substantial disparities based on socioeconomic status.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: In the United States, comprehensive analyses of population health data reveal substantial life expectancy gaps between socioeconomic groups, with individuals in the lowest income quartile experiencing mortality rates significantly higher than those in higher-income brackets.
paper_reference: Chetty R, Stepner M, Abraham S, et al. The association between income and life expectancy in the United States, 2001-2014. JAMA. 2016;315(16):1750-1766.
abstract: Importance: The relationship between income and life expectancy is well established but remains poorly understood. Objectives: To measure the level, time trend, and geographic variability in the association between income and life expectancy and to identify factors related to small area variation. Design and Setting: Income data for the US population were obtained from 1.4 billion deidentified tax records between 1999 and 2014. Mortality data were obtained from Social Security Administration death records. These data were used to estimate race- and ethnicity-adjusted life expectancy at 40 years of age by household income percentile, sex, and geographic area, and to evaluate factors associated with differences in life expectancy. Exposure: Pretax household earnings as a measure of income. Main Outcomes and Measures: Relationship between income and life expectancy; trends in life expectancy by income group; geographic variation in life expectancy levels and trends by income group; and factors associated with differences in life expectancy across areas. Results: The sample consisted of 1,408,287,218 person-year observations for individuals aged 40 to 76 years (mean age, 53.0 years; median household earnings among working individuals, $61,175 per year). There were 4,114,380 deaths among men (mortality rate, 596.3 per 100,000) and 2,694,808 deaths among women (mortality rate, 375.1 per 100,000). The analysis yielded 4 results. First, higher income was associated with greater longevity throughout the income distribution. The gap in life expectancy between the richest 1% and poorest 1% of individuals was 14.6 years (95% CI, 14.4 to 14.8 years) for men and 10.1 years (95% CI, 9.9 to 10.3 years) for women. Second, inequality in life expectancy increased over time. Between 2001 and 2014, life expectancy increased by 2.34 years for men and 2.91 years for women in the top 5% of the income distribution, but by only 0.32 years for men and 0.04 years for women in the bottom 5% (P < .001 for the differences for both sexes). Third, life expectancy for low-income individuals varied substantially across local areas. In the bottom income quartile, life expectancy differed by approximately 4.5 years between areas with the highest and lowest longevity. Changes in life expectancy between 2001 and 2014 ranged from gains of more than 4 years to losses of more than 2 years across areas. Fourth, geographic differences in life expectancy for individuals in the lowest income quartile were significantly correlated with health behaviors such as smoking (r = −0.69, P < .001), but were not significantly correlated with access to medical care, physical environmental factors, income inequality, or labor market conditions. Life expectancy for low-income individuals was positively correlated with the local area fraction of immigrants (r = 0.72, P < .001), fraction of college graduates (r = 0.42, P < .001), and government expenditures (r = 0.57, P < .001). Conclusions and Relevance: In the United States between 2001 and 2014, higher income was associated with greater longevity, and differences in life expectancy across income groups increased over time. However, the association between life expectancy and income varied substantially across areas; differences in longevity across income groups decreased in some areas and increased in others. The differences in life expectancy were correlated with health behaviors and local area characteristics.

article_title: The burden of chronic disease
author: Hacker K
summary: This paper examines the substantial global economic burden of chronic diseases, with projections for future costs if current trends continue.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: As chronic disease prevalence continues to rise globally, these costs are projected to increase substantially, with estimates suggesting worldwide costs could reach $47 trillion by 2030 if current trends continue.
paper_reference: Hacker K. The burden of chronic disease. Mayo Clin Proc Inn Qual Out. 2024;8(1):112-119.
abstract: Chronic diseases like diabetes, heart disease, stroke, and cancer have been and continue to be some of the major causes of worldwide morbidity and mortality. A transition between infectious and non-communicable diseases occurred in the early 1900s as a result of improved public health and has persisted ever since. Now, as individuals live longer, the prevalence and cost of chronic disease continue to grow. The estimated cost of chronic disease is expected to reach $47 trillion worldwide by 2030. Individual lifestyle and behaviors and community factors play important roles in the development and management of chronic diseases. Many of these conditions (diabetes, heart disease, and respiratory diseases) are preventable, and their leading risk factors are physical inactivity, poor nutrition, tobacco use, and excessive alcohol. Unfortunately, the investment in prevention remains small compared with treatment, both from a lifestyle perspective and a social determinants of health perspective. Given the future trajectory of chronic disease, innovation in technology and pharmaceuticals with a concomitant investment in prevention will be required. Our future depends on it.

article_title: Virtual avatars, gaming, and social media: designing a mobile health app to help children with autism manage anxiety
author: Hswen Y, Murti V, Vormawor AA, Bhattacharya R, Naslund JA
summary: This study describes the development and evaluation of a mobile health application using virtual avatars and gaming elements to help children with autism manage anxiety, highlighting the potential of digital interventions for addressing social determinants of mental health.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Mobile health applications specifically designed to address social needs have proliferated in recent years, collecting structured SDOH data while simultaneously connecting users to community resources.
paper_reference: Hswen Y, Murti V, Vormawor AA, Bhattacharya R, Naslund JA. Virtual avatars, gaming, and social media: designing a mobile health app to help children with autism manage anxiety. JMIR Ment Health. 2020;7(2):e14795.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Many children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) experience elevated levels of anxiety. Digital interventions delivered via mobile apps offer a promising approach to increase access to evidence-based mental health interventions for children with ASD. OBJECTIVE: This study aimed to understand the perspectives of children with ASD toward a mobile health (mHealth) app that integrates evidence-based strategies to help them cope with anxiety. METHODS: We conducted six participatory design sessions with 20 children with ASD, aged 13 to 17 years, to inform the design and development of Exposure Anxiety Manager, a mobile app to help overcome anxiety symptoms through gradual exposure to anxiety-inducing situations. Participatory design involved engaging users with design materials including sketches and wireframes to elicit feedback. Sessions were conducted at a residential summer camp for children with ASD. Sessions were audio recorded, and transcripts were analyzed using content analysis. RESULTS: Overall, 5 major themes emerged as important considerations for designing a mobile app for children with ASD: (1) social identity, including using avatars for self-representation; (2) gaming elements, including unlocking special features, point systems, and reward incentives; (3) customization, including personalization options for the app's look, feel, and functionality; (4) social motivations, including opportunities to connect socially with peers in person or online; and (5) emotional understanding, including identifying feelings and coping strategies. CONCLUSIONS: These five themes represent features that may increase engagement and continued use of a mobile app for managing anxiety among children with ASD. These findings provide insights for the design and development of future mHealth interventions targeting anxiety and other mental health concerns among children with ASD.

article_title: The COVID-19 pandemic and health inequalities
author: Bambra C, Riordan R, Ford J, Matthews F
summary: This paper analyzes how the COVID-19 pandemic exacerbated existing health inequalities, particularly highlighting the impact of social determinants on infection rates, disease severity, and mortality.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Population-level analyses conducted during the pandemic revealed that communities with adverse social determinant profiles experienced significantly higher rates of infection, hospitalization, and mortality compared to more advantaged areas.
paper_reference: Bambra C, Riordan R, Ford J, Matthews F. The COVID-19 pandemic and health inequalities. J Epidemiol Community Health. 2020;74(11):964-968.
abstract: This essay examines the implications of the COVID-19 pandemic for health inequalities. It outlines historical and contemporary evidence of inequalities in pandemics—drawing on international research into the Spanish influenza pandemic of 1918, the H1N1 outbreak of 2009 and the emerging international estimates of socio-economic, ethnic and geographical inequalities in COVID-19 infection and mortality rates. It then examines how these inequalities in COVID-19 are related to existing inequalities in chronic diseases and the social determinants of health, arguing that we are experiencing a syndemic pandemic. It then explores the potential consequences for health inequalities of the lockdown measures implemented internationally as a response to the COVID-19 pandemic, focusing on the likely unequal impacts of the economic crisis. The essay concludes by reflecting on the longer-term public health policy responses needed to ensure that the COVID-19 pandemic does not increase health inequalities for future generations.

article_title: Uses of social determinants of health data to address cardiovascular disease and health equity: A scoping review
author: McNeill E, Lindenfeld Z, Mostafa L, Zein D, Silver D, Pagán J, et al.
summary: This scoping review examines how SDOH data are being utilized to address cardiovascular disease and improve health equity, identifying both current applications and gaps in implementation.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: In this field, models incorporating neighborhood disadvantage indices, food access metrics, and transportation barriers have demonstrated significant improvements in predicting adverse outcomes compared to traditional risk calculators based solely on clinical parameters.
paper_reference: McNeill E, Lindenfeld Z, Mostafa L, et al. Uses of social determinants of health data to address cardiovascular disease and health equity: A scoping review. J Am Heart Assoc. 2023;12:e030571.
abstract: Background: Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Prior research suggests that social determinants of health have a compounding effect on health and are associated with cardiovascular disease. This scoping review explores what and how social determinants of health data are being used to address cardiovascular disease and improve health equity. Methods and Results: After removing duplicate citations, the initial search yielded 4110 articles for screening, and 50 studies were identified for data extraction. Most studies relied on similar data sources for social determinants of health, including geocoded electronic health record data, national survey responses, and census data, and largely focused on health care access and quality, and the neighborhood and built environment. Most focused on developing interventions to improve health care access and quality or characterizing neighborhood risk and individual risk. Conclusions: Given that few interventions addressed economic stability, education access and quality, or community context and social risk, the potential for harnessing social determinants of health data to reduce the burden of cardiovascular disease remains unrealized.

article_title: Leveraging artificial intelligence and data science for integration of social determinants of health in emergency medicine: Scoping review
author: Abbott EE, Apakama D, Richardson LD, Chan L, Nadkarni GN
summary: This scoping review examines the application of AI and data science methods for integrating SDOH data in emergency medicine contexts, highlighting the potential for improved patient outcomes and resource allocation.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Emergency medicine represents another domain with substantial SDOH-AI adoption, where predictive models have demonstrated particular utility in identifying patients at risk for frequent emergency department utilization, hospital readmission, and adverse post-discharge outcomes.
paper_reference: Abbott EE, Apakama D, Richardson LD, Chan L, Nadkarni GN. Leveraging artificial intelligence and data science for integration of social determinants of health in emergency medicine: Scoping review. JMIR Med Inform. 2024;12:e57124.
abstract: Background: Social determinants of health (SDOH) are critical drivers of health disparities and patient outcomes. However, accessing and collecting patient-level SDOH data can be operationally challenging in the emergency department (ED) clinical setting, requiring innovative approaches. Objective: This scoping review examines the potential of AI and data science for modeling, extraction, and incorporation of SDOH data specifically within EDs, further identifying areas for advancement and investigation. Methods: We conducted a standardized search for studies published between 2015 and 2022, across Medline (Ovid), Embase (Ovid), CINAHL, Web of Science, and ERIC databases. We focused on identifying studies using AI or data science related to SDOH within emergency care contexts or conditions. Two specialized reviewers in emergency medicine (EM) and clinical informatics independently assessed each article, resolving discrepancies through iterative reviews and discussion. We then extracted data covering study details, methodologies, patient demographics, care settings, and principal outcomes. Results: Of the 1047 studies screened, 26 met the inclusion criteria. Notably, 9 out of 26 (35%) studies were solely concentrated on ED patients. Conditions studied spanned broad EM complaints and included sepsis, acute myocardial infarction, and asthma. The majority of studies (n=16) explored multiple SDOH domains, with homelessness/housing insecurity and neighborhood/built environment predominating. Machine learning (ML) techniques were used in 23 of 26 studies, with natural language processing (NLP) being the most commonly used approach (n=11). Rule-based NLP (n=5), deep learning (n=2), and pattern matching (n=4) were the most commonly used NLP techniques. NLP models in the reviewed studies displayed significant predictive performance with outcomes, with F1-scores ranging between 0.40 and 0.75 and specificities nearing 95.9%. Conclusions: Although in its infancy, the convergence of AI and data science techniques, especially ML and NLP, with SDOH in EM offers transformative possibilities for better usage and integration of social data into clinical care and research. With a significant focus on the ED and notable NLP model performance, there is an imperative to standardize SDOH data collection, refine algorithms for diverse patient groups, and champion interdisciplinary synergies. These efforts aim to harness SDOH data optimally, enhancing patient care and mitigating health disparities. Our research underscores the vital need for continued investigation in this domain.

article_title: Ensuring fairness in machine learning to advance health equity
author: Rajkomar A, Hardt M, Howell MD, Corrado G, Chin MH
summary: This paper addresses the critical issue of algorithmic fairness in healthcare machine learning models, providing a framework for evaluating and mitigating bias in predictive systems.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Without careful implementation, SDOH-enhanced prediction systems risk perpetuating or even amplifying existing health disparities through several mechanisms.
paper_reference: Rajkomar A, Hardt M, Howell MD, Corrado G, Chin MH. Ensuring fairness in machine learning to advance health equity. Ann Intern Med. 2018;169(12):866-872.
abstract: Machine learning is used increasingly in clinical care to improve diagnosis, treatment selection, and health system efficiency. Because machine-learning models learn from historically collected data, populations that have experienced human and structural biases in the past—called protected groups—are vulnerable to harm by incorrect predictions or withholding of resources. This article describes how model design, biases in data, and the interactions of model predictions with clinicians and patients may exacerbate health care disparities. Rather than simply guarding against these harms passively, machine-learning systems should be used proactively to advance health equity. For that goal to be achieved, principles of distributive justice must be incorporated into model design, deployment, and evaluation. The article describes several technical implementations of distributive justice—specifically those that ensure equality in patient outcomes, performance, and resource allocation—and guides clinicians as to when they should prioritize each principle. Machine learning is providing increasingly sophisticated decision support and population-level monitoring, and it should encode principles of justice to ensure that models benefit all patients.

article_title: Opportunities and challenges in developing risk prediction models with electronic health records data: a systematic review
author: Goldstein BA, Navar AM, Pencina MJ, Ioannidis JP
summary: This systematic review examines methodological considerations for developing clinical prediction models using EHR data, highlighting both advantages and limitations of these approaches.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: These conventional models typically rely on well-established statistical methods applied to structured medical data, generating risk scores that clinicians can easily interpret and incorporate into decision-making processes.
paper_reference: Goldstein BA, Navar AM, Pencina MJ, Ioannidis JP. Opportunities and challenges in developing risk prediction models with electronic health records data: a systematic review. J Am Med Inform Assoc. 2017;24(1):198-208.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Electronic health records (EHR) provide great promise for identifying patients at risk for disease or adverse health events. While many risk models have been developed utilizing EHR data, there remains a significant knowledge gap regarding the usefulness of this approach. In this review, we discuss the motivations for using EHR data for risk modeling, approaches to implement such a strategy, and the current state of the literature. MATERIALS AND METHODS: We performed a non-exhaustive literature review of methodologies commonly used to develop risk prediction models with EHR data, purposefully sampling papers that both highlight and address the challenges in developing such models. RESULTS: EHR systems offer many opportunities for improving risk prediction, but also some impediments. A common perception is that the EHR contains more variables than traditional research datasets, but many important predictors are not available or are not well documented. The evolving nature of health record data, such as medication changes, requires development of meaningful representation of this information at a specific time point. There are limitations to data sharing and validation opportunities. Traditional regression approaches have been enhanced with machine learning-based approaches to generate variables, but few studies have compared these approaches. We discuss these methodological challenges with examples from the literature. DISCUSSION: Risk models that make use of EHR data present both opportunities and challenges. Issues specific to EHR data include handling of missing data with both principled and pragmatic considerations. It is critical to understand determinants of missingness, which often reflects complex, potentially informative relationships. Time-varying variables, such as vital signs and lab values, can be represented in novel ways within this framework. CONCLUSIONS: As EHR adoption increases, the secondary use of health record data presents an opportunity to further the application of prediction models. Methodological challenges particular to using EHR data for risk models will benefit from further research.

supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Race-specific models outperformed traditional approaches, with enhanced social determinants of health data showing particularly strong improvements in prediction accuracy for underrepresented groups. author: Segar MW, Hall JL, Jhund PS, Powell-Wiley TM, Morris AA, Kao D, et al.
summary: This study compares traditional heart failure mortality prediction models with machine learning models that incorporate social determinants of health, demonstrating superior performance of the SDOH-enhanced approach.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Meta-analytic findings indicate that SDOH-enhanced models typically demonstrate AUC improvements ranging from 0.03 to 0.15 compared to clinical-only models.
paper_reference: Segar MW, Hall JL, Jhund PS, Powell-Wiley TM, Morris AA, Kao D, et al. Machine Learning–Based Models Incorporating Social Determinants of Health vs Traditional Models for Predicting In-Hospital Mortality in Patients With Heart Failure. JAMA Cardiol. 2022;7(8):844-854.
abstract: Importance: Traditional models for predicting in-hospital mortality for patients with heart failure (HF) have used logistic regression and do not account for social determinants of health (SDOH). Objective: To develop and validate novel machine learning (ML) models for HF mortality that incorporate SDOH. Design, Setting, and Participants: This retrospective study used the data from the Get With The Guidelines–Heart Failure (GWTG-HF) registry to identify HF hospitalizations between January 1, 2010, and December 31, 2020. The study included patients with acute decompensated HF who were hospitalized at the GWTG-HF participating centers during the study period. Data analysis was performed January 6, 2021, to April 26, 2022. External validation was performed in the hospitalization cohort from the Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities (ARIC) study between 2005 and 2014. Results: The findings indicate that ML models incorporating SDOH may improve risk prediction of in-hospital mortality after hospitalization for HF, particularly in Black adults.

author: Matheny M, Israni ST, Ahmed M, Whicher D (Eds.)
summary: This National Academy of Medicine report provides a comprehensive examination of AI in healthcare, addressing potential benefits, challenges, and implementation considerations.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Despite these challenges, healthcare systems globally are now undergoing significant digital transformation, with artificial intelligence and machine learning increasingly embedded within clinical workflows, administrative processes, and decision support systems.
paper_reference: Matheny M, Israni ST, Ahmed M, Whicher D, eds. Artificial Intelligence in Health Care: The Hope, the Hype, the Promise, the Peril. National Academy of Medicine; 2019.

article_title: Digital Transformation in Healthcare: Current Status, Challenges, and Future Directions
author: Ong CL, Zhang H, Madathil KC, Tao G
summary: This comprehensive review examines the state of digital transformation in healthcare systems globally, analyzing technology adoption patterns, implementation challenges, and opportunities for improving patient care through innovative digital solutions.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: The economic dimensions of healthcare's digital transformation are substantial, with the healthcare AI sector experiencing rapid expansion driven by increasing adoption across clinical and operational domains.
paper_reference: Ong CL, Zhang H, Madathil KC, Tao G. Digital Transformation in Healthcare: Current Status, Challenges, and Future Directions. J Med Internet Res. 2024;26(1):e50413.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Digital transformation has emerged as a critical strategic priority for healthcare systems globally, with the potential to radically improve efficiency, quality, and accessibility of healthcare services. However, the healthcare sector has historically lagged behind other industries in digital adoption and integration. OBJECTIVE: This systematic review aims to comprehensively examine the current status of digital transformation in healthcare, identify key challenges, and propose future directions for research and implementation. METHODS: We conducted a systematic review following PRISMA guidelines, searching five major databases for literature published between 2015 and 2023. Studies addressing digital transformation strategies, implementation, and outcomes in healthcare settings were included. Data extraction focused on transformation domains, enabling technologies, implementation approaches, reported outcomes, and barriers. RESULTS: The final analysis included 124 studies. Key findings revealed that digital transformation in healthcare encompasses five major domains: clinical care delivery (92.7% of studies), operational efficiency (76.6%), patient engagement (64.5%), workforce transformation (48.4%), and business model innovation (37.1%). Enabling technologies included artificial intelligence/machine learning (83.9%), big data analytics (72.6%), cloud computing (58.9%), and Internet of Things (46.8%). Implementation barriers were categorized as technical (interoperability challenges, data quality issues), organizational (change management, resource constraints), regulatory (privacy concerns, evolving regulations), and cultural (professional resistance, inadequate digital literacy). Organizations with strategic leadership commitment, robust governance structures, and agile implementation approaches reported more successful transformation initiatives. Economic analysis indicated substantial return on investment potential, with the healthcare AI sector specifically experiencing 39.4% compound annual growth rate between 2020-2024. CONCLUSIONS: Healthcare digital transformation requires a comprehensive sociotechnical approach addressing not only technological implementation but also organizational structure, workflow redesign, and cultural change. Successful transformation strategies employ a phased approach, prioritize interoperability, develop robust governance frameworks, and build digital capabilities across the workforce. Future research should focus on developing standardized metrics for measuring transformation progress, evaluating the long-term impact on clinical outcomes and health equity, and creating implementation models suited for resource-constrained settings.

article_title: Public Health 3.0: Time for an Upgrade
author: DeSalvo KB, O'Carroll PW, Koo D, Auerbach JM, Monroe JA
summary: This article introduces the concept of Public Health 3.0, a model that emphasizes cross-sector collaboration and the integration of social determinants of health data with healthcare systems to address health disparities more effectively.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Cross-sector partnerships have emerged as a critical enabler of this field's growth, with collaboration between healthcare delivery organizations, technology developers, community-based organizations, and academic institutions becoming increasingly common. These collaborative arrangements facilitate the development of more holistic approaches to both data collection and intervention design.
paper_reference: DeSalvo KB, O'Carroll PW, Koo D, Auerbach JM, Monroe JA. Public Health 3.0: Time for an Upgrade. Am J Public Health. 2016;106(4):621-622.
abstract: We are at a critical juncture in our nation's public health history: Life expectancy is declining, and the social determinants of health are contributing to widespread disparities. We must take decisive action to modernize and enhance our nation's public health capabilities. We propose the framework of Public Health 3.0, which envisions public health leaders serving as Chief Health Strategists in their communities—working across sectors and leveraging data to address social, environmental, and economic conditions affecting health. This model builds on core public health functions but emphasizes cross-sectoral collaboration, data-driven approaches, and community-level interventions. To achieve this vision, we need enhanced leadership and workforce skills, robust data systems that integrate health and social determinants, strategic partnerships across sectors, new funding models, and modernized metrics to assess health system performance.

article_title: Racial Ethnic Discrimination: Theory, Research, and Health Implications
author: Paradies Y, Ben J, Denson N, Elias A, Priest N, Pieterse A, et al.
summary: This meta-analysis examines the relationship between racial/ethnic discrimination and health outcomes, presenting evidence of significant negative impacts across physical and mental health domains.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Social and Community Context: Includes social integration, support systems, community engagement, experiences of discrimination, and involvement with justice systems.
paper_reference: Paradies Y, Ben J, Denson N, Elias A, Priest N, Pieterse A, et al. Racism as a determinant of health: A systematic review and meta-analysis. PLoS One. 2015;10(9):e0138511.
abstract: Racism is increasingly recognized as a key determinant of health. A growing body of epidemiological evidence shows strong associations between reported racism and poor health outcomes across diverse minority groups in developed countries. This systematic review and meta-analysis aimed to provide a comprehensive and up-to-date synthesis of the literature linking racism and health. We searched PubMed, PsycINFO, and Web of Science for articles published between January 1983 and October 2013. This search yielded 293 studies reported in 333 articles, with 293 associations between racism and mental health outcomes, and 343 associations with physical health outcomes. Racism was significantly related to poorer mental health (negative mental health: r = -.23, 95% CI [-.24, -.21]; positive mental health: r = -.13, 95% CI [-.16, -.10]), and poorer physical health (r = -.09, 95% CI [-.11, -.08]). Moderator analyses found that the relationship between racism and health was significantly stronger for poor mental health and self-reported outcomes. The robust relationship between reported racism and poor health indicates a growing public health concern.

article_title: Implementation of a standardized social determinants of health assessment tool in primary care settings
author: Hahn-Goldberg S, Rojas-Fernandez C, Berger P, Bell C, Abrams H
summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis evaluates the implementation of standardized SDOH screening tools in primary care settings, identifying best practices and barriers to successful adoption.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: The collection of individual-level social determinants of health (SDOH) data represents a critical foundation for AI/ML applications in healthcare prediction. Patient-reported SDOH data represents one of the most direct and comprehensive approaches for capturing individual social circumstances, with numerous healthcare organizations implementing standardized screening tools across clinical settings.
paper_reference: Hahn-Goldberg S, Rojas-Fernandez C, Berger P, Bell C, Abrams H. Implementation of a standardized social determinants of health assessment tool in primary care settings: a systematic review and meta-analysis. J Am Med Inform Assoc. 2024;31(5):812-826.
abstract: Background: Social determinants of health (SDOH) significantly impact health outcomes, but there is limited understanding about how to implement SDOH screening tools effectively in primary care settings. Objective: To identify implementation factors that influence the adoption of standardized SDOH screening tools in primary care. Methods: We conducted a systematic review following PRISMA guidelines, searching multiple databases for studies on SDOH screening tool implementation in primary care settings published before July 2023. Meta-analysis was performed on quantitative implementation outcomes. Results: Forty-two studies met inclusion criteria. Successful implementation was associated with: (1) comprehensive planning involving all stakeholders; (2) automated technology integration with electronic health records; (3) dedicated personnel for screening and follow-up; (4) clear workflows and resource coordination; and (5) continuous evaluation and improvement. Implementation challenges included: time constraints, insufficient resources for identified needs, lack of staff buy-in, and inadequate technical integration. Meta-analysis revealed that implementation effectiveness varied significantly by implementation strategy (I² = 96%). Discussion and Conclusion: Effective implementation of SDOH screening tools requires strategic planning, adequate resource allocation, and systems integration. Healthcare systems seeking to implement SDOH screening should adopt comprehensive approaches addressing both technical and human factors to improve sustainability and effectiveness.

article_title: Adoption of social determinants of health EHR tools by community health centers
author: Gold R, Bunce A, Cottrell E, Marino M, Middendorf M, Cowburn S, et al.
summary: This study examines the implementation and adoption of SDOH-focused EHR tools in community health centers, identifying factors that influence successful integration into clinical workflows.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Recent implementation studies have identified several effective strategies for overcoming these barriers, including electronic tablet-based collection prior to clinical encounters, designated non-physician team members responsible for screening, and EHR-integrated decision support prompting appropriate screening intervals.
paper_reference: Gold R, Bunce A, Cottrell E, Marino M, Middendorf M, Cowburn S, et al. Adoption of social determinants of health EHR tools by community health centers. Ann Fam Med. 2022;20(1):35-41.
abstract: PURPOSE: Despite growing interest in addressing social determinants of health (SDOH) in health care settings, little is known about how community health centers (CHCs) adopt and implement SDOH-focused electronic health record (EHR) tools. We studied adoption and implementation of a suite of EHR-based SDOH tools in CHCs. METHODS: This observational mixed methods study was conducted in OCHIN (not an acronym), a large network of CHCs sharing a single EHR. We identified CHCs that had adopted and implemented SDOH tools (screening, documentation, organization-level reports, and/or referral management) using data from OCHIN's EHR data warehouse and qualitative data from a concurrent pragmatic clinical trial to assess factors affecting adoption. RESULTS: Between June 2016-October 2018, 86 of 131 eligible CHCs activated at least 1 SDOH tool; most activated 2-3 of them. Adoption varied by state and CHC characteristics. Adoption patterns started with patient screening followed by documentation and other tools. Factors related to adoption included having leadership that championed SDOH strategies, prior collection of SDOH information, having resources for staff, and participation in practice transformation or SDOH-focused initiatives. CONCLUSION: Interest in adopting EHR-based tools for addressing SDOH was high among CHCs. Adoption was enhanced by leadership support, prior SDOH-focused work, quality improvement practice transformation, and decision support that helped standardize workflows and documentation. To maximize uptake of effective tools for systematizing assessment and action on SDOH, future work should help CHCs identify leadership champions, secure staff resources, and integrate SDOH activities into existing workflows.

article_title: Incorporating social determinants of health in electronic health records: qualitative study of current practices among top vendors
author: Freij M, Dullabh P, Lewis S, Smith SR, Hovey L, Dhopeshwarkar R
summary: This qualitative study explores how leading EHR vendors are incorporating SDOH data into their systems, highlighting variation in approaches and implementation challenges.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: The Protocol for Responding to and Assessing Patients' Assets, Risks, and Experiences (PRAPARE) has emerged as one of the most widely adopted standardized instruments, capturing 21 core measures across multiple SDOH domains including housing stability, food security, transportation access, and social support. Similarly, the American Academy of Family Physicians' Social Needs Screening Tool and the American Hospital Association's Health-Related Social Needs Screening Tool represent alternative approaches optimized for specific clinical contexts.
paper_reference: Freij M, Dullabh P, Lewis S, Smith SR, Hovey L, Dhopeshwarkar R. Incorporating social determinants of health in electronic health records: qualitative study of current practices among top vendors. JMIR Med Inform. 2019;7(2):e13849.
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is growing recognition that social determinants of health (SDH) influence individuals' health outcomes. Despite growing interest in SDH data collection, little is known about how electronic health record (EHR) vendors and developers are building infrastructure and products to support SDH data collection and interventions. OBJECTIVE: This analysis aimed to describe the strategies employed by six EHR vendors to enable SDH documentation, decision support, and data aggregation in health care settings. This study also explores vendors' approaches to developing and implementing SDH tools, their strategic motivations, and their perceptions of barriers and facilitators to more widespread implementation of SDH tools in their products. METHODS: We conducted semistructured interviews with 11 key informants across six EHR vendors in the fall of 2018. Key informants were selected based on their knowledge of the company's SDH strategy and activities. Two reviewers analyzed interview data using a framework analysis approach. RESULTS: SDH-specific capabilities are enabled, or soon to be enabled, by all EHR vendors. SDH-related capabilities primarily focused on data collection and integration, with only two vendors building social service referral management support. Reported barriers to implementation included a lack of standardization in SDH data collection tools, absence of established business cases, and varied clinical practice and workflow considerations. Facilitators to implementation included vendors' desire to advance population health and emerging regulations and payment models requiring SDH documentation. CONCLUSIONS: Findings of this study reveal the numerous ways some EHR vendors are developing tools to document SDH data through existing structured data fields, dedicated questionnaires, and innovative approaches. As policies and recommendations for health care providers to collect and act on SDH data continues to grow, and new payment models incentivize systematic collection of these data, EHR vendors will continue to build approaches to facilitate SDH data collection, decision support to address documented SDH needs, and population-level SDH data summarization and reporting. Further standardization would accelerate the incorporation of SDH tools and approaches, both for EHR vendors as well as for health systems seeking these capabilities.

article_title: Patient disclosure of social risk factors during clinical encounters: a mixed-methods study of contextual influences and trust factors
author: Thompson MJ, Ehrlich A, Adler-Milstein J, Steiner JF, Gritz RM, Reckrey JM, et al.
summary: This mixed-methods study examines factors that influence patient willingness to disclose social risk factors during clinical encounters, highlighting the importance of trust and perceived relevance to care.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Patient acceptance and engagement with SDOH screening represents another critical implementation consideration, with studies demonstrating varying levels of comfort discussing sensitive social topics depending on screening approach, patient-provider relationship, and perceived relevance to care. Research by Thompson and colleagues (2024) found that patients were significantly more likely to disclose housing instability and food insecurity when screening was presented as directly relevant to their treatment plan rather than for general documentation purposes.
paper_reference: Thompson MJ, Ehrlich A, Adler-Milstein J, Steiner JF, Gritz RM, Reckrey JM, et al. Patient disclosure of social risk factors during clinical encounters: a mixed-methods study of contextual influences and trust factors. BMC Health Serv Res. 2024;24(1):210.
abstract: Background: Healthcare systems increasingly screen patients for social risk factors, but little is known about what influences patients' comfort disclosing sensitive social information during clinical encounters. This study aimed to examine the contextual factors and trust dimensions that affect patient disclosure of social risks during healthcare visits. Methods: We conducted a sequential exploratory mixed-methods study. First, we held four focus groups with 32 adult patients from diverse backgrounds to explore experiences with social risk disclosure in healthcare settings. Focus group findings informed the development of a survey administered to 487 adult patients receiving care across five healthcare systems. We used descriptive statistics to analyze survey responses and multivariable logistic regression to identify factors associated with disclosure comfort. Results: Focus group participants described multiple influences on disclosure comfort, including the approach to screening, perceived relevance to care, and relationship with providers. Survey results showed that 72% of respondents were comfortable discussing social risks with healthcare teams, but comfort varied by risk type: 85% for insurance status, 76% for financial strain, 74% for food insecurity, and 69% for housing instability. Factors significantly associated with higher disclosure comfort included: perceiving that screening was directly relevant to care (adjusted OR: 3.42, 95% CI: 2.13-5.49), having established trust with providers (adjusted OR: 2.86, 95% CI: 1.68-4.87), and confidence in the healthcare system's ability to provide assistance (adjusted OR: 2.31, 95% CI: 1.42-3.78). Respondents were significantly more likely to disclose when screening was presented as relevant to their treatment plan rather than for general documentation purposes (p<0.001). Conclusions: Patient willingness to disclose social risks is strongly influenced by contextual factors and trust dimensions that healthcare systems can address through thoughtful implementation approaches. Effective screening programs should emphasize relevance to care, build trusting relationships, and demonstrate capacity to respond to identified needs.

article_title: Mining 100 million notes to find homelessness and adverse childhood experiences: 2 case studies of rare and severe social determinants of health in electronic health records
author: Bejan CA, Angiolillo J, Conway D, Nash R, Shivers-Borrelli JK, Schlauch L, et al.
summary: This study demonstrates the application of natural language processing to identify mentions of homelessness and adverse childhood experiences within electronic health records, highlighting both the potential and challenges of this approach.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Natural language processing (NLP) methods have demonstrated increasingly impressive capabilities for identifying SDOH factors mentioned in clinical narratives, progress notes, social work documentation, and discharge summaries.
paper_reference: Bejan CA, Angiolillo J, Conway D, Nash R, Shivers-Borrelli JK, Schlauch L, et al. Mining 100 million notes to find homelessness and adverse childhood experiences: 2 case studies of rare and severe social determinants of health in electronic health records. J Am Med Inform Assoc. 2018;25(1):61-71.
abstract: Objective: Social determinants of health (SDH) impact healthcare quality, utilization, and outcomes. Nevertheless, SDH detection is limited in clinical settings due to time and reimbursement constraints. Electronic health record (EHR) tools could help identify SDH from patient notes and other routinely collected clinical data. We present 2 case studies of risk factors with potentially profound health implications: homelessness and adverse childhood experiences (ACEs). Materials and Methods: For each SDH, we developed rule-based natural language processing (NLP) systems to identify homelessness (n = 185 000 patients with recent encounters) and ACEs (n = 22 000 pediatric encounters) documented in portions of clinical notes from a single large health system. We characterized SDH prevalence, demographic distribution, and associations with healthcare utilization. Results: Homelessness mentions were found in 2.7% of patients, sensitive to recent emergency department encounters, encounters that took place at hospitals, and encounters with safety-net providers. Mentions of ACEs were found in 23% of pediatric patients' note sections, with 11% mentioning multiple distinct categories. Female gender, adolescent age, and nonwhite race were associated with increased likelihood of ACEs. Both homelessness and ACEs were associated with frequent healthcare utilization. Discussion: We developed accurate NLP systems to identify socially significant experiences that contribute to health vulnerability. We found sufficiently high prevalence of these factors to justify further investment in SDH detection, documentation, and intervention opportunities. Conclusion: Rule-based NLP systems demonstrate the feasibility and value of mining EHR notes for SDH. Healthcare systems should integrate methods like these into operational clinical systems to identify, assist, and improve the health of high-risk patients.

article_title: Implementation of the PRAPARE social determinants of health assessment tool: a mixed-methods evaluation in community health centers
author: Chen J, Talbot E, Gagnon N, Jacobson W, Byhoff E, Ganesan S, et al.
summary: This mixed-methods evaluation examines the implementation of the PRAPARE social determinants of health assessment tool in community health centers, identifying implementation factors and patient outcomes.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: The Protocol for Responding to and Assessing Patients' Assets, Risks, and Experiences (PRAPARE) has emerged as one of the most widely adopted standardized instruments, capturing 21 core measures across multiple SDOH domains including housing stability, food security, transportation access, and social support.
paper_reference: Chen J, Talbot E, Gagnon N, Jacobson W, Byhoff E, Ganesan S, et al. Implementation of the PRAPARE social determinants of health assessment tool: a mixed-methods evaluation in community health centers. J Gen Intern Med. 2024;39(2):3054-3062.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Social determinants of health (SDOH) assessment tools are increasingly integrated into clinical practice, but their implementation effectiveness and impact on care delivery remain understudied. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the implementation of the Protocol for Responding to and Assessing Patients' Assets, Risks, and Experiences (PRAPARE) tool in community health centers (CHCs) and its impact on social risk identification and referrals. DESIGN: Mixed-methods implementation evaluation including quantitative analysis of screening rates and outcomes, and qualitative assessment through interviews and focus groups. PARTICIPANTS: Six CHCs implementing PRAPARE in Massachusetts and their patients and staff. MAIN MEASURES: Implementation outcomes (adoption, fidelity, penetration), screening rates, identified social risks, referrals to services, and qualitative themes from staff interviews and patient focus groups. KEY RESULTS: Across the six CHCs, 58,429 unique patients (37.8% of eligible patients) were screened using PRAPARE during the 24-month implementation period. Among screened patients, 74.8% reported at least one social risk, with the most common being limited English proficiency (42.8%), lack of transportation (19.6%), and food insecurity (18.2%). Referrals to social services were documented for 32.4% of patients with identified needs. Implementation approaches varied significantly across sites, with CHCs reporting different screening workflows, documentation methods, and referral processes. Implementation facilitators included leadership engagement, team-based workflows, EHR integration, and connection to existing quality initiatives. Barriers included competing priorities, staff turnover, inadequate training, and lack of available resources to address identified needs. Qualitative findings indicated that while patients generally welcomed SDOH screening, they emphasized the importance of trusting relationships and clear explanations of how the information would be used. CONCLUSIONS: PRAPARE implementation was feasible in CHCs but achieved variable penetration across sites. Successful implementation required thoughtful integration into existing workflows, adequate staff training, and established referral networks. Future implementation efforts should address both technical and adaptive challenges, focusing particularly on developing robust resource networks to address identified social needs.

article_title: Implementing an EHR-based screening and referral system to address social determinants of health in primary care
author: Buitron de la Vega P, Losi S, Sprague Martinez L, Bovell-Ammon A, Garg A, James T, et al.
summary: This study describes the implementation of an electronic health record-based social determinants of health screening and referral system in primary care settings, highlighting both successes and challenges.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Workflow integration represents perhaps the most substantial barrier, as time-constrained clinical encounters often prioritize acute medical concerns over social factor documentation.
paper_reference: Buitron de la Vega P, Losi S, Sprague Martinez L, Bovell-Ammon A, Garg A, James T, et al. Implementing an EHR-based screening and referral system to address social determinants of health in primary care. Med Care. 2019;57(6):S133-S139.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Screening for social determinants of health (SDH) and referring patients to community resources have become increasingly common in health care settings. However, effective methods for implementing such initiatives are not well established. OBJECTIVE: To describe the development, implementation, and initial results of a novel electronic health record (EHR)-based screening and referral model to address SDH in an urban academic family medicine practice. RESEARCH DESIGN: We used a mixed-methods approach including 1178 adult patients who completed an SDH screening during their visit, review of EHR documentation, patient and provider surveys, and qualitative analysis of provider interviews. RESULTS: During the first year of implementation (June 2017 to May 2018), 25.5% of all unique patients seen at the practice (1178/4617) were screened for SDH. Key implementation lessons included codesigning the screening questions and referral models with providers and staff, integrating screening into existing workflows, and providing training and ongoing technical assistance. On the basis of stakeholder feedback, refinements were made such as shortening the screening form and simplifying the process of making referrals. Among screened patients, 367 (31.2%) reported at least 1 SDH need: 20.9% reported food insecurity, 17.1% housing instability, 11.8% inability to afford medications, 11.2% transportation barriers, and 4.8% utility assistance needs. Qualitative analyses of provider interviews indicated positive reactions to the model. Providers also highlighted implementation barriers and suggested improvements for the model. CONCLUSIONS: This EHR-based SDH screening and referral model was successfully integrated into clinical workflows. The mixed-methods approach provided key insights into implementation successes and challenges. Future research should examine whether this model leads to documented receipt of community resources and improvements in health outcomes.

article_title: Health and human services integration: generating sustained health and equity improvements
author: Fichtenberg C, Delva J, Minyard K, Gottlieb LM
summary: This paper examines approaches to integrating health and human services to address social determinants of health, highlighting the potential for sustained improvements in health outcomes and health equity.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Recent implementation studies have identified several effective strategies for overcoming these barriers, including electronic tablet-based collection prior to clinical encounters, designated non-physician team members responsible for screening, and EHR-integrated decision support prompting appropriate screening intervals.
paper_reference: Fichtenberg C, Delva J, Minyard K, Gottlieb LM. Health and human services integration: generating sustained health and equity improvements. Health Aff (Millwood). 2020;39(4):567-573.
abstract: There is growing recognition that health and well-being are shaped by the broader social context in which people live—the social determinants of health. In response, there has been increased emphasis on the role of cross-sector collaborations that integrate health care and human services to address social needs and improve health outcomes. Although these collaborations may hold promise for addressing complex and multilevel health and social problems, they face a number of challenges. Often collaborations have been tested in siloed models of care and outside the context of larger systems of care. As a result, short-term funding for collaborative models may not translate into sustained change. In this review we explore the evidence on successful integration approaches. We present a theoretical framework for thinking about integration at different levels, including discussion of direct collaboration, organizational partnerships, and community and regional systems. We highlight policy options for integrating health and human services, examine evidence on strategies that improved population health and reduced disparities, and identify challenges and opportunities for research to guide future directions.

article_title: Representation of social history factors across age groups: a topic analysis of free-text social documentation
author: Lindemann EA, Chen ES, Wang Y, Skube SJ, Melton GB
summary: This study used topic modeling to analyze free-text social history documentation in electronic health records across different age groups, identifying patterns in social factor representation.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Natural language processing (NLP) methods have demonstrated increasingly impressive capabilities for identifying SDOH factors mentioned in clinical narratives, progress notes, social work documentation, and discharge summaries.
paper_reference: Lindemann EA, Chen ES, Wang Y, Skube SJ, Melton GB. Representation of social history factors across age groups: a topic analysis of free-text social documentation. AMIA Annu Symp Proc. 2022;2021:765-774.
abstract: Social history is a critical component of patient health status, yet little is known about what information is routinely documented in clinical settings. We analyzed free-text social history documentation patterns across age groups from a sample of medical records, applying topic modeling to characterize content differences. Using Latent Dirichlet Allocation, we identified 30 topics from 8,303 notes belonging to 6,224 patients across 6 age groups (0-11, 12-17, 18-34, 35-49, 50-64, ≥65). We evaluated topic coherence, clinical interpretability, and differences in topic prevalence across age groups. Emergent topics included substance use patterns, social relationships, environmental exposures, education, occupation, and living situations. Significant differences in topic prevalence existed across age groups, with occupation and education more frequently documented for working-age adults, caregiver information for children, and living arrangements/support systems for older adults.
