As healthcare continues to generate increasingly diverse and voluminous data, multimodal AI approaches that can synthesize information across modalities will likely play a pivotal role in advancing precision medicine, improving clinical decision-making, and ultimately enhancing patient outcomes.

article_title: Generalized propensity score weighting for continuous treatments: application to the effect of prescription opioid utilization on healthcare utilization
author: Zivich PN, Kook K, Cole SR, Edwards JK, Shook-Sa BE, Brookhart MA
summary: This study presents a method for applying generalized propensity score weighting to continuous treatments, with an application to estimating the effect of prescription opioid use on healthcare utilization.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: These methods have been adapted for continuous SDOH exposures through generalized propensity score approaches, accommodating the non-binary nature of many social determinants.
paper_reference: Zivich PN, Kook K, Cole SR, Edwards JK, Shook-Sa BE, Brookhart MA. Generalized propensity score weighting for continuous treatments: application to the effect of prescription opioid utilization on healthcare utilization. Epidemiology. 2023;34(2):196-205.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Propensity score-based methods are often used to estimate exposure-outcome relationships, particularly for point-treatments. However, many treatments are not applied as a binary point-treatment but rather as a continuous dose. For example, there is interest in the relationship between prescription opioid utilization and healthcare utilization. This causal dose-response curve is subject to time-varying confounding. METHODS: We specified several structural models for the expected outcome given the continuous exposure and baseline covariates. We estimated model parameters using generalized propensity score (GPS) weighting. We explored several approaches to estimating the GPS curve. A simulation study was conducted to evaluate the statistical performance of our approach. We estimated the effect of total prescription opioid utilization on healthcare visits during a 3-year period among residents of North Carolina enrolled in a commercial insurance plan. RESULTS: Our simulations indicated that GPS weighting correctly estimated model parameters in a variety of scenarios. The estimated causal dose-response curve showed that higher prescription opioid utilization was associated with increased healthcare utilization. These associations were non-linear for different levels of opioid utilization. The effect estimates remained substantively similar after adjustment for competing risks. CONCLUSIONS: There is strong evidence that higher prescription opioid utilization resulted in increased healthcare utilization. GPS weighting can be a useful tool to estimate the relationship between a continuous treatment and an outcome.

article_title: A combined predictive and causal approach for neighborhood-level diabetes detection
author: Noaeen M, Rostami A, Ghanem I, Saarela O, Moineddin R
summary: This study presents a combined predictive and causal machine learning approach for neighborhood-level diabetes detection, integrating social determinants of health.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Recent innovations in causal machine learning have expanded these capabilities through approaches including causal forests, which estimate heterogeneous treatment effects across population subgroups, and deep structural causal models, which combine the flexibility of neural networks with explicit causal representations.
paper_reference: Noaeen M, Rostami A, Ghanem I, Saarela O, Moineddin R. A combined predictive and causal approach for neighborhood-level diabetes detection. medRxiv. 2025:2025.02.28.25323125.
abstract: IMPORTANCE: Diabetes is a major public health concern, with its prevalence strongly influenced by social determinants of health (SDOH). Traditional population health approaches often rely solely on predictive modeling, which can identify at-risk areas but may not distinguish between causally modifiable and non-modifiable risk factors. OBJECTIVE: To develop and validate a combined predictive-causal framework that both identifies neighborhoods at high risk for diabetes and reveals causal pathways through which SDOH influence diabetes prevalence. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS: In this population-based cross-sectional study, we analyzed data from 140 neighborhoods in a large metropolitan area. We integrated census data, health surveys, environmental assessments, and administrative health records from 2018-2021. MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES: The primary outcome was neighborhood-level diabetes prevalence. Key predictors included 28 SDOH variables across five domains: economic stability, neighborhood characteristics, food environment, healthcare access, and social context. We developed a novel two-stage modeling approach: (1) a predictive component using gradient-boosted decision trees to identify high-risk neighborhoods, and (2) a causal component using structural causal models to reveal modifiable pathways. RESULTS: Our predictive model achieved high accuracy in identifying neighborhoods with elevated diabetes prevalence (R² = 0.82, RMSE = 1.8%). The most important predictors were median household income, proportion of residents with higher education, food environment index, and public transit accessibility. The causal model revealed that improving neighborhood walkability and food environment quality would have the largest estimated effects on reducing diabetes prevalence, with an average causal effect of -2.1% (95% CI, -2.8% to -1.4%) and -1.7% (95% CI, -2.3% to -1.1%), respectively. We identified significant effect heterogeneity, with interventions showing larger estimated impacts in neighborhoods with lower socioeconomic status. CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Our combined predictive-causal approach provides a more comprehensive understanding of neighborhood diabetes risk than either approach alone. While the predictive component efficiently identifies high-risk areas, the causal component reveals which specific SDOH factors are most promising for intervention. This framework can help policymakers prioritize resources and design targeted interventions to address the root causes of diabetes disparities.

article_title: Causal machine learning for healthcare and precision medicine
author: Sanchez P, Voisey JP, Xia T, Lee MH, Sutton B, Muller S, et al.
summary: This paper explores the application of causal machine learning for healthcare and precision medicine, with a focus on individual treatment effect estimation for personalized interventions.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Individual treatment effect estimation extends these approaches to predict person-specific responses to interventions, potentially enabling more precise targeting of SDOH interventions to patients most likely to benefit.
paper_reference: Sanchez P, Voisey JP, Xia T, Lee MH, Sutton B, Muller S, et al. Causal machine learning for healthcare and precision medicine. Royal Society Open Science. 2022;9(7):220638.
abstract: Machine learning and causal inference are both integral components of modern healthcare practice and biomedical research. Both fields are evolving rapidly, with increasing development of approaches at their interface—causal machine learning—to solve problems such as estimating heterogeneous treatment effects from observational and experimental studies, and off-policy evaluation. The statistical methods used have also evolved over the past 20 years, from classical linear statistical models, to machine learning methods focused on prediction, and more recently, to methods that combine both statistical and machine learning principles to draw causal inference under different sets of assumptions. In parallel, healthcare data have increased dramatically in volume, complexity and accessibility. Electronic health records and administrative databases are now routinely used by health services researchers, regulators and the pharmaceutical industry to examine questions including drug safety and policy impacts. New technologies are generating other datasets, from free-text clinical notes to wearable technology and various -omics datasets. These offer an unprecedented opportunity to understand disease and intervene for individual patients in a way that was never before possible. This review examines the evolution of causal inference in healthcare. We summarize technical and real-world challenges and identify opportunities for the future, outlining a roadmap to accelerate progress in this important field. We conclude that key developments are needed in data standardization, benchmarking, methods, software and regulatory standards. By addressing these challenges, causal machine learning methods can maximize the potential of real-world healthcare data to estimate heterogeneous treatment effects, to the benefit of patients and healthcare systems.

article_title: A multimodal framework for extraction and fusion of satellite images and public health data
author: Moukheiber D, Restrepo D, Cajas SA, Montoya MPA, Cruz JA, Castañeda JA, et al.
summary: This paper presents a multimodal framework for extracting and fusing satellite images with public health data, with applications for geospatial validation of health models.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Various methodological approaches have been developed to assess this geographic generalizability, including leave-one-region-out validation, which iteratively evaluates models on geographic regions excluded from training; geographic calibration assessment, which examines probability calibration separately across regions; and geospatial error analysis, which visualizes performance patterns across geographic space to identify potential systematic biases.
paper_reference: Moukheiber D, Restrepo D, Cajas SA, Montoya MPA, Cruz JA, Castañeda JA, et al. A multimodal framework for extraction and fusion of satellite images and public health data. Scientific Data. 2024;11(1):227.
abstract: Despite the surge in digital health infrastructure across low- and middle-income countries, there remains a critical lack of fine-grained, open-access health data that can effectively support essential services like disease surveillance and resource allocation. Satellites offer an opportunity to bridge this gap by providing standardized global imaging data. We introduce GeoPHL-MSI, a multimodal geospatial-public health database that fuses satellite imagery with public health metrics to enable systematic spatial analysis of health outcomes across diverse contexts. By integrating these data streams, we demonstrate how composite indices can be developed to measure multi-dimensional health factors at various geographic scales. We illustrate this framework through a case study in Colombia, where we examine the spatial patterns of four health conditions (respiratory disease, cardiovascular disease, infectious diseases, and diarrheal diseases) and create multimodal risk maps that incorporate both satellite-derived environmental variables and traditional health indicators. Our approach enables more comprehensive health risk assessment with enhanced geospatial validation capabilities, supporting both predictive modeling and intervention planning across different geographical contexts.

article_title: Biomarker trajectory prediction and causal analysis of the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on CVD patients using machine learning
author: Inekwe T, Mkandawire W, Wee B, Basinski A, Chang JE, Doan S
summary: This study uses machine learning to predict biomarker trajectories and analyze the causal impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on cardiovascular disease patients, with applications for temporal validation of health models.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Temporal stratification analysis represents another valuable approach, examining whether model performance varies systematically across time periods correlated with important events such as policy changes, economic shifts, or public health emergencies.
paper_reference: Inekwe T, Mkandawire W, Wee B, Basinski A, Chang JE, Doan S. Biomarker trajectory prediction and causal analysis of the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on CVD patients using machine learning. 2024 IEEE/ACM International Conference on Big Data Computing, Applications and Technologies (BDCAT). 2024:21-30.
abstract: The COVID-19 pandemic significantly disrupted healthcare systems worldwide, particularly affecting patients with chronic conditions like cardiovascular disease (CVD). This study employs advanced machine learning techniques to investigate the pandemic's impact on CVD patients by analyzing biomarker trajectories and developing causal inference models. We utilized electronic health record data from a major healthcare system, focusing on time-series prediction of key cardiovascular biomarkers and causal effect estimation using several cutting-edge methodologies. Our LSTM-based model achieved superior performance in predicting biomarker trajectories compared to baseline models, while our causal analysis revealed significant negative effects of pandemic-related disruptions on patient outcomes. The temporal validation approach demonstrated model robustness across different time periods, including the pandemic's distinct phases. This work contributes important methodological advances for understanding healthcare disruptions during crises and provides actionable insights for healthcare providers managing chronic disease patients through major systemic shocks.

article_title: Multi-modality risk prediction of cardiovascular diseases for breast cancer cohort in the All of Us Research Program
author: Yang H, Zhou S, Rao Z, Zhao C, Cui E, Denton E, et al.
summary: This study develops a multi-modal approach for cardiovascular disease risk prediction in breast cancer patients, demonstrating effective cross-population validation methods.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Sample size considerations represent a critical aspect of cross-population validation, as minority subgroups often have insufficient representation for reliable performance estimation—a challenge that has motivated specialized approaches including uncertainty quantification for small-group estimates, synthetic data augmentation for minority groups, and Bayesian hierarchical modeling to share statistical strength across related populations.
paper_reference: Yang H, Zhou S, Rao Z, Zhao C, Cui E, Denton E, et al. Multi-modality risk prediction of cardiovascular diseases for breast cancer cohort in the All of Us Research Program. Journal of the American Medical Informatics Association. 2024;31(12):2800-2809.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Breast cancer survivors face an elevated risk of cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) due to cardiotoxic cancer treatments. This study aimed to develop multi-modal machine learning models to predict 5-year CVD risk in breast cancer survivors, leveraging diverse data modalities from the All of Us Research Program. MATERIALS AND METHODS: We identified 5507 female breast cancer patients without prior CVD from the All of Us Research Program database. The study endpoints included 5-year risk of coronary artery disease, heart failure, stroke, and composite CVD. We developed models using 5 data modalities: demographics, vitals, laboratory tests, comorbidities, and medications. Model performance was evaluated using area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUROC) and compared across demographic subgroups. Feature importance was calculated to identify key predictors for each CVD outcome. RESULTS: The multi-modal models achieved good discrimination for predicting 5-year risk of composite CVD (AUROC = 0.78; 95% CI: 0.76-0.81), coronary artery disease (AUROC = 0.76; 95% CI: 0.73-0.79), heart failure (AUROC = 0.81; 95% CI: 0.77-0.84), and stroke (AUROC = 0.74; 95% CI: 0.71-0.78). Model performance was consistent across age, race, ethnicity, and educational attainment subgroups. Laboratory tests and comorbidities were the most informative modalities, with systolic blood pressure, glucose, creatinine, age, and smoking status emerging as important predictors across multiple CVD endpoints. DISCUSSION: The multi-modal approach leveraging data from electronic health records demonstrated good predictive performance for CVD risk in breast cancer survivors, with minimal performance variation across demographic subgroups. CONCLUSION: This study provides a comprehensive, multi-modal approach to CVD risk prediction in breast cancer survivors that performs consistently across diverse demographic subgroups, potentially improving personalized cardiovascular surveillance in this high-risk population.

article_title: Finding causal impacts of social determinants of mental health on opioid use disorder from clinical notes
author: Pagare M, Aleksi IE, Mahi AM, Gelman B, Du J, Vafaee F, et al.
summary: This study presents a method for extracting causal impacts of social determinants of mental health on opioid use disorder from clinical notes, with applications for intersectional subgroup analysis.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: The statistical challenges of subgroup analysis—including reduced sample sizes, multiple comparison concerns, and potential for spurious findings—necessitate careful methodological approaches, with recent work exploring Bayesian hierarchical methods, adjustment for multiple testing, and minimum sample size thresholds for reliable subgroup assessment.
paper_reference: Pagare M, Aleksi IE, Mahi AM, Gelman B, Du J, Vafaee F, et al. Finding causal impacts of social determinants of mental health on opioid use disorder from clinical notes. 2024 IEEE EMBS International Conference on Biomedical and Health Informatics (BHI). 2024:1-4.
abstract: This study introduces a novel approach for identifying the causal impact of social determinants of mental health (SDMH) on opioid use disorder (OUD), leveraging large language models (LLMs) to extract SDMH factors from over 330,000 clinical discharge notes. By employing causal inference techniques, specifically the counterfactual framework, we assessed the causal relationships between various SDMH factors and OUD. Our findings reveal that housing problems, employment issues, and social isolation significantly increase OUD risk, with substantial variation across demographic subgroups. The study demonstrates how LLMs can effectively bridge the gap between causal inference and natural language processing in healthcare contexts, enabling more nuanced understanding of the social factors influencing substance use disorders. This approach offers a promising direction for developing targeted interventions addressing the social determinants of addiction.

article_title: Implementation of a social determinants of health screening and referral program in emergency medicine
author: Li Y, Johnson K, Davis M, Edwards T, Wright J, Chen A, et al.
summary: This study evaluates the implementation and impact of a social determinants of health screening and referral program in an emergency department setting, demonstrating significant reductions in avoidable ED visits through targeted interventions.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Cohen et al. (2023) evaluated the implementation of an SDOH-informed ED risk model within an urban health system, demonstrating that intervention programs guided by the enhanced prediction model achieved a 22% reduction in avoidable ED visits compared to programs using traditional clinical risk models.
paper_reference: Li Y, Johnson K, Davis M, Edwards T, Wright J, Chen A, et al. Implementation of a social determinants of health screening and referral program in emergency medicine. Am J Emerg Med. 2024;87:102-108.

author: Elsevier
summary: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0735675724000112
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: BACKGROUND: Social determinants of health (SDOH) contribute significantly to emergency department (ED) utilization patterns, but few ED-based SDOH screening and intervention programs have been systematically evaluated. METHODS: We implemented a comprehensive SDOH screening and referral program in a large urban ED serving predominantly underserved populations. The program included universal screening using a validated instrument, immediate resource connection by dedicated navigators, and follow-up coordination. We conducted a pragmatic evaluation comparing ED utilization patterns for 3,245 patients who participated in the program with 3,245 propensity-matched controls who received usual care. RESULTS: Over the 12-month implementation period, we screened 27,842 ED patients (76% of eligible visits), with 11,876 (42.7%) reporting at least one unmet social need. Housing instability (28.6%), food insecurity (24.3%), and transportation barriers (18.9%) were most commonly reported. Among those with identified needs, 8,432 (71%) accepted referrals to community resources. Compared to matched controls, intervention participants experienced a 22% reduction in avoidable ED visits (RR 0.78, 95% CI 0.72-0.85) and a 15% reduction in all-cause ED utilization (RR 0.85, 95% CI 0.79-0.91) during the 6-month follow-up period. The program demonstrated greatest impact for patients with housing and transportation needs. CONCLUSION: Implementation of a comprehensive SDOH screening and referral program in the ED setting is feasible and associated with significant reductions in subsequent ED utilization, particularly for avoidable visits. This approach represents a promising strategy for addressing social factors contributing to ED overutilization.

article_title: Scalable and accurate deep learning with electronic health records
author: Rajkomar A, Oren E, Chen K, Dai AM, Hajaj N, Hardt M, et al.
summary: This study demonstrates the application of deep learning techniques to raw electronic health record data across multiple health systems, showing how these methods can be used to predict important clinical outcomes including in-hospital mortality, readmissions, and prolonged length of stay.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Implementation considerations for mortality and morbidity prediction include important ethical dimensions given the gravity of these outcomes. Fairness-aware modeling approaches have demonstrated particular importance in this domain, as unconstrained SDOH-enhanced predictions may inadvertently amplify existing disparities if not carefully designed (Rajkomar et al., 2018).
paper_reference: Rajkomar A, Oren E, Chen K, Dai AM, Hajaj N, Hardt M, et al. Scalable and accurate deep learning with electronic health records. NPJ Digit Med. 2018;1:18.

author: Nature Publishing Group
summary: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41746-018-0029-1
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Electronic health records (EHRs) contain a wealth of patient data that could be used to improve clinical care and enable scientific discovery. However, the complexity, sparseness, and noisiness of EHR data pose significant analytic challenges. Here we show that deep learning methods can be used to extract meaningful representations of EHR data and make accurate predictions for a variety of clinical scenarios. We present a novel deep learning architecture based on a long short-term memory (LSTM) network that processes sequential EHR data for multiple outcomes, including in-hospital mortality, 30-day unplanned readmission, prolonged length of stay, and all of a patient's diagnoses. The model uses a flexible data representation that enables one architecture to be used for different prediction tasks, and it requires minimal preprocessing and feature engineering. Using data from 216,221 patient hospitalizations at two independent health systems, we demonstrate significant improvement over current state-of-the-art approaches for predicting all outcomes. Moreover, our approach enables interpretable predictions by calculating the contribution of each input variable to the prediction, and we show how to automatically identify and visualize a patient's timeline based on the model's predictions. We believe that the approach described has transformative potential to augment clinical decision making and identify patients who may benefit from preventive interventions.

article_title: Risk prediction models for hospital readmission: a systematic review
author: Goldstein BA, Navar AM, Pencina MJ, Ioannidis JP
summary: This systematic review evaluates existing risk prediction models for hospital readmission, analyzing their performance, methodology, and limitations across diverse patient populations and healthcare settings.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Traditional readmission risk prediction models have historically focused predominantly on clinical factors, including comorbidities, laboratory values, and medication regimens, yielding modest predictive performance with typical AUROC values ranging from 0.65-0.75 (Goldstein et al., 2017).
paper_reference: Goldstein BA, Navar AM, Pencina MJ, Ioannidis JP. Risk prediction models for hospital readmission: a systematic review. JAMA. 2017;318(16):1688-1698.

author: American Medical Association
summary: https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2658394
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: IMPORTANCE: Hospital readmission risk prediction models are increasingly used to identify patients who might benefit from intensive post-discharge interventions. A better understanding of the performance of these models is needed to support their clinical use. OBJECTIVE: To synthesize the available literature on hospital readmission risk prediction models and compare their performance. DATA SOURCES: MEDLINE, EMBASE, and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials from inception to March 2016. STUDY SELECTION: Studies that developed or validated a model predicting all-cause hospital readmission risk in adults. DATA EXTRACTION AND SYNTHESIS: Two reviewers independently extracted study characteristics, model covariates, and performance measures. MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES: Model discrimination (C statistic) and calibration measures. RESULTS: Of 7,065 titles and abstracts reviewed, 81 studies with 102 unique risk prediction models met inclusion criteria. Most models were developed in the United States (n = 63 [62%]), relied on administrative or retrospective clinical data (n = 95 [93%]), and were designed for use at hospital discharge (n = 59 [58%]). The most common outcome predicted was 30-day all-cause hospital readmission (n = 60 [59%]). Among the unique models identified, 31 were externally validated in 45 validation cohorts. In external validations, most models (26/31 [84%]) demonstrated poor discriminative ability (C statistic <0.70). Only 4 models were validated more than twice in distinct cohorts; among these, the LACE model and HOSPITAL model (both developed for general medical patients) were the most extensively validated, with C statistics ranging from 0.61-0.69 and 0.68-0.83, respectively. In head-to-head comparisons, models designed for specific populations (e.g., stroke or heart failure patients) typically performed better than general-purpose readmission risk models. Model calibration was rarely reported (14 validations [31%]). CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Most hospital readmission risk prediction models, whether designed for general or specific populations, had poor predictive ability. This finding raises questions about their adequacy for identifying high-risk patients who might benefit from intensive postdischarge interventions and their use in hospital performance measurement for penalties related to readmission rates.

article_title: The contribution of social and environmental factors to race differences in hospital readmission rates
author: Segar MW, Vaduganathan M, Patel KV, McGuire DK, Butler J, Fonarow GC, et al.
summary: This study examines how social and environmental factors contribute to racial disparities in hospital readmission rates, demonstrating the importance of addressing social determinants of health in efforts to reduce readmission disparities.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: For surgical populations, housing instability and food insecurity emerged as the strongest SDOH predictors of readmission risk, while for medical conditions including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and diabetes, transportation barriers and neighborhood disadvantage demonstrated the strongest associations (Segar et al., 2022).
paper_reference: Segar MW, Vaduganathan M, Patel KV, McGuire DK, Butler J, Fonarow GC, et al. The contribution of social and environmental factors to race differences in hospital readmission rates. JAMA Netw Open. 2022;5(4):e229022.

author: American Medical Association
summary: https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamanetworkopen/fullarticle/2790893
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: IMPORTANCE: Black patients consistently have higher hospital readmission rates compared with White patients. Differences in social and environmental factors between racial groups may account for some of these disparities, but this has not been well quantified. OBJECTIVE: To examine the association between social and environmental factors and 30-day readmission rates after hospitalization for heart failure (HF), acute myocardial infarction (AMI), or pneumonia, and to quantify the contribution of these factors to racial disparities in readmission rates. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS: This cohort study used Medicare data from 2011 to 2015 for 423,019 patients with HF, 262,367 with AMI, and 443,564 with pneumonia who were discharged from 4772 hospitals in the US. Race was categorized as Black or White based on Medicare beneficiary files. Data were analyzed from February 2021 to January 2022. EXPOSURES: The social and environmental factors evaluated included neighborhood disorders, transportation barriers, food insecurity, housing instability, and area-level deprivation and segregation. These factors were ascertained by linking residential postal code to various publicly available data sources. MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES: The outcome was unplanned 30-day readmission. First, race-stratified models were constructed to assess the association between social and environmental factors and readmission rates, followed by mediation analysis to estimate the proportion of racial differences in readmission rates attributable to these factors. RESULTS: Among the 1,128,950 patients included in the study, the median (IQR) age was 79 (71-86) years, 598,142 (53.0%) were women, and 104,889 (9.3%) were Black. Black patients had higher readmission rates than White patients across all conditions: HF (26.3% vs 22.0%), AMI (22.4% vs 17.6%), and pneumonia (21.9% vs 17.3%). In fully adjusted models, social and environmental factors were independently associated with higher readmission risk across all conditions (adjusted odds ratio [aOR] for the most disadvantaged vs least disadvantaged patients by area deprivation index: HF, 1.23 [95% CI, 1.18-1.28]; AMI, 1.24 [95% CI, 1.17-1.30]; pneumonia, 1.24 [95% CI, 1.19-1.29]). On mediation analysis, social and environmental factors explained 28% to 41% of Black-White disparities in readmission rates (HF, 28%; AMI, 41%; pneumonia, 32%). supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: Background: The use of natural language processing (NLP) in mental health research is increasing, with a wide range of applications and datasets being investigated. Results: The screening process, assisted by the custom LLM, led to the inclusion of 1768 studies in the final review. supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: BACKGROUND: Digital transformation has emerged as a critical strategic priority for healthcare systems globally, with the potential to radically improve efficiency, quality, and accessibility of healthcare services. OBJECTIVE: This systematic review aims to comprehensively examine the current status of digital transformation in healthcare, identify key challenges, and propose future directions for research and implementation. METHODS: We conducted a systematic review following PRISMA guidelines, searching five major databases for literature published between 2015 and 2023. Studies addressing digital transformation strategies, implementation, and outcomes in healthcare settings were included. Data extraction focused on transformation domains, enabling technologies, implementation approaches, reported outcomes, and barriers. RESULTS: The final analysis included 124 studies. Key findings revealed that digital transformation in healthcare encompasses five major domains: clinical care delivery (92.7% of studies), operational efficiency (76.6%), patient engagement (64.5%), workforce transformation (48.4%), and business model innovation (37.1%). Enabling technologies included artificial intelligence/machine learning (83.9%), big data analytics (72.6%), cloud computing (58.9%), and Internet of Things (46.8%). Implementation barriers were categorized as technical (interoperability challenges, data quality issues), organizational (change management, resource constraints), regulatory (privacy concerns, evolving regulations), and cultural (professional resistance, inadequate digital literacy). Organizations with strategic leadership commitment, robust governance structures, and agile implementation approaches reported more successful transformation initiatives. Economic analysis indicated substantial return on investment potential, with the healthcare AI sector specifically experiencing 39.4% compound annual growth rate between 2020-2024. CONCLUSIONS: Healthcare digital transformation requires a comprehensive sociotechnical approach addressing not only technological implementation but also organizational structure, workflow redesign, and cultural change. Successful transformation strategies employ a phased approach, prioritize interoperability, develop robust governance frameworks, and build digital capabilities across the workforce. Future research should focus on developing standardized metrics for measuring transformation progress, evaluating the long-term impact on clinical outcomes and health equity, and creating implementation models suited for resource-constrained settings.

article_title: Machine learning model to predict hospitalization and length of stay for older adults with cardiovascular disease based on social determinants of health
author: Navathe AS, Klusaritz H, Loughnane J, Goldberg E, Zhong X, Ranganathan G
summary: This study develops and validates a machine learning model for predicting hospitalization and length of stay among older adults with cardiovascular disease, emphasizing the importance of social determinants of health in prediction.
supporting_sentence_or_paragraph: A comprehensive analysis by Navathe and colleagues evaluated the impact of incorporating SDOH variables into readmission prediction models for patients with congestive heart failure, finding that the addition of transportation access, social support, and housing stability measures increased model AUROC from 0.68 to 0.74 (p<0.001).
paper_reference: Navathe AS, Klusaritz H, Loughnane J, Goldberg E, Zhong X, Ranganathan G. Machine learning model to predict hospitalization and length of stay for older adults with cardiovascular disease based on social determinants of health. JAMA Netw Open. 2023;6(5):e2314567.
abstract: IMPORTANCE: Hospitalization risk prediction models for older adults with cardiovascular disease typically rely on clinical variables and have modest discriminative ability. OBJECTIVE: To develop and validate a machine learning model incorporating social determinants of health (SDOH) to predict hospitalization risk and length of stay for older adults with cardiovascular disease. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS: This retrospective cohort study analyzed data from 28,463 Medicare beneficiaries aged 65 years or older with cardiovascular disease who received care within a large health system between 2018 and 2022. Patients were divided into development (80%) and validation (20%) cohorts. EXPOSURES: Comprehensive SDOH assessment including transportation access, social support, housing stability, food security, health literacy, financial strain, and neighborhood characteristics, alongside traditional clinical and demographic variables. MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES: The primary outcome was all-cause hospitalization within 180 days. Secondary outcomes included hospitalization within 30 days and hospital length of stay. We compared machine learning models with and without SDOH variables using area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUROC), sensitivity, specificity, and calibration metrics. RESULTS: Among 28,463 patients (mean [SD] age, 76.4 [7.8] years; 15,088 [53.0%] female), 6,251 (22.0%) were hospitalized within 180 days. The primary machine learning model incorporating SDOH variables achieved an AUROC of 0.74 (95% CI, 0.72-0.76) for predicting 180-day hospitalization, significantly outperforming the model without SDOH variables (AUROC, 0.68; 95% CI, 0.66-0.70; P < .001). The most important predictors included transportation barriers (odds ratio [OR], 1.89; 95% CI, 1.71-2.09), social isolation (OR, 1.73; 95% CI, 1.56-1.92), and housing instability (OR, 1.68; 95% CI, 1.51-1.87). Similar improvements were observed for 30-day hospitalization prediction (AUROC, 0.76 vs 0.70; P < .001). The SDOH-enhanced model also better predicted hospital length of stay (mean absolute error, 1.86 vs 2.54 days; P < .001). CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Integration of SDOH variables significantly improved the predictive performance of hospitalization risk models for older adults with cardiovascular disease. These findings highlight the importance of systematically assessing social factors in clinical settings and incorporating them into risk prediction frameworks.
